snippet: Cuba’s success in limiting the epidemic stems partly from harsh early tactics and universal basic health care.
abstract: Cuba's success in limiting its AIDS epidemic stems from a number of factors, most notably a harsh quarantine system that existed until 1993; rates have also dropped off due to rigorous HIV testing under the country's universal basic health care system, free condoms and graphic safe-sex education for teenagers. Photos (L)
lead_paragraph: HAVANA -- Yudelsy García O'Connor, the first baby known to have been born with H.I.V. in Cuba, is not merely still alive. She is vibrant, funny and, at age 25, recently divorced but hoping to remarry and have children. Her father died of AIDS when she was 10, her mother when she was 23. She was near death herself in her youth.

headline.main: A Regime's Tight Grip on AIDS
